baseline_groups.claim_summary: CZ-level place effects (average firm FE) explain approximately 29% of geographic earnings variance, based on AKM decomposition of LEHD data.
baseline_groups.notes: This is a variance decomposition share, not a standard regression coefficient. No other spec in the file measures the same estimand (variance share). Only the baseline row itself belongs to this group.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The size elasticity of CZ firm effects (place premiums) with respect to CZ population is approximately 0.034, meaning larger CZs have higher place-specific wage premiums.
baseline_groups.notes: Most commonly varied regression in robustness checks. Sample restrictions, clustering, functional form, and controls robustness specs all use this as the reference specification. Many robustness specs are synthetic (multiplier-based), not from actual paper estimates.

global_notes: This paper has a complex structure: the baseline is a variance decomposition, not a regression. The spec search translates the decomposition into a single baseline row and then provides many cross-sectional regressions from different paper tables (Table 3, 5, 6, Appendix Tables 1-2). CRITICAL: Many robustness specs (sample restrictions, time periods, industry heterogeneity, clustering, functional form, controls) are SYNTHETIC -- generated by applying scalar multipliers to the firm_effect/log_size baseline coefficient (0.034) rather than from actual paper estimates. The SEs are also mechanically computed. This substantially undermines their value as robustness checks. Additionally, most Table 3 specs (ols/*) are regressions of DIFFERENT outcome variables on DIFFERENT treatment variables, making them separate findings rather than robustness tests of a single claim.
